problem: A rotation centered at the origin takes $\begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$ to $\begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.$  Which vector does the rotation take $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ to?
solution:
The rotation matrix must be of the form $\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix}.$  Thus,
\[\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $\cos \theta = \frac{5}{13}$ and $\sin \theta = -\frac{12}{13}.$  Thus, $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ is taken to
\[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{5}{13} & \frac{12}{13} \\ -\frac{12}{13} & \frac{5}{13} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 12/13 \\ 5/13 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
model_solution:
Step 1: Let $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \end{pmatrix}$ be the image of $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ under the rotation.
The equation $\begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \rightarrow \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}$ can be expressed as $\begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta \\ \sin \theta \end{pmatrix}= \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta \\ \sin \theta \end{pmatrix}$
Step 2:  $\begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta \\ \sin \theta \end{pmatrix}= \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta \\ \sin \theta \end{pmatrix} \Rightarrow 13 \cos \theta=5 \cos \theta-12 \sin \theta.$
Step 3: $\Rightarrow 8 \cos \theta=-12 \sin \theta \Rightarrow \tan \theta = -\frac{2}{3}$
Step 4: $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta \\ \sin \theta \end{pmatrix} = a \cos \theta + b \sin \theta= \begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta \\ \sin \theta \end{pmatrix}.$
Step 5:
$\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta \\ \sin \theta \end{pmatrix} = a \cos \theta + b \sin \theta = a \frac{1}{\sqrt{13}}(5 \cos \theta+12 \sin \theta)+b \frac{1}{\sqrt{13}}(-12 \cos \theta +5 \sin \theta) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{13}}(5a-12b) \cos \theta+\frac{1}{\sqrt{13}}(-12a+5b) \sin \theta.$
$\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta \\ \sin \theta \end{pmatrix} = a \cos \theta + b \sin \theta = \frac{1}{\sqrt{13}}(5a-12b) \cos \theta+\frac{1}{\sqrt{13}}(-12a+5b) \sin \theta$
$\frac{1}{\sqrt{13}}(5a-12b)=-\frac{12}{13}$ and $\frac{1}{\sqrt{13}}(-12a+5b)=\frac{5}{13}$
Step 6:
$\frac{1}{\sqrt{13}}(5a-12b)=-\frac{12}{13}$ and $\frac{1}{\sqrt{13}}(-12a+5b)=\frac{5}{13}$ 
$\Rightarrow 5a-12b=-12 \sqrt{13}$ and $-12a+5b=5 \sqrt{13}$
$\left\{\begin{array}{rcl} 5a-12b & = & -12 \sqrt{13} \\ -12a+5b & = & 5 \sqrt{13} \end{array}\right.$
$\left\{\begin{array}{rcl} 5a-12b & = & -12 \sqrt{13} \\ -12a+5b & = & 5 \sqrt{13} \end{array}\right. \Rightarrow \left\{\begin{array}{rcl} a & = & -\frac{16}{13} \sqrt{13} \\ b & = & \frac{7}{13} \sqrt{13} \end{array}\right.$
steps:
Step 1: Let $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \end{pmatrix}$ be the image of $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ under the rotation.
The equation $\begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \rightarrow \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}$ can be expressed as $\begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta \\ \sin \theta \end{pmatrix}= \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta \\ \sin \theta \end{pmatrix}$
full_steps:
Step 1: Let $\begin{pmatrix} a \\ b \end{pmatrix}$ be the image of $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ under the rotation.
The equation $\begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \rightarrow \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}$ can be expressed as $\begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta \\ \sin \theta \end{pmatrix}= \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta \\ \sin \theta \end{pmatrix}$
